JULIAN HUXLEY TO
SPEAK AT HOPKINS
Will Talk on "Travels and
Politics in Africa"
MADE AFRICAN TOUR
To Lecture For Williams Foundation
Julian Huxley, famous English
writer and biologist, will lecture at
Hopkins on Tuesday, November
11, at 5 P. M. in room 120, C. E.
Building, Professor Lancaster,
chairman of the committee on lectures, announced today. Professor
Huxley is the grandson of the faMous Thomas H. Huxley, Victorian
apostle of evolution.
Professor Huxley is professor of
zoology at King's College, London.
He is famous for his research as a
biologist and for his books and
magazine articles. He is co-author
With H. G. Wells of The Science of
Life, which is soon to be published,
and has also written The Individual
in the Animal Kingdom, Essays of
a Biologist, The Stream of Life and
Essays in Popular Science. He has
also been a constant contributor to
well-known English and American
authors.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 31, 1930

SENIOR PICTURES TO
BE TAKEN NEXT WEEK
Robert Mille r, business
manager of the Hullabaloo,
announced today that the pictures of the individual members of the Senior class will
be taken by the White Studios
starting early next week.
All Seniors are urgently requested to report to the Hullabaloo office for appointments
for individual sittings starting
Monday from 12:20 to 1 :00
P. M. Promptness will save
time and energy and will result in better service, it was
stated.

Price 5 Cents

TURNBULL HEADS
STATE SCORERS
Leading 45 scorers in college football this season, Jack
Turnbull, Hopkins gridiron
star, has, to date chalked up 45
points. Seven touchdowns and
three successful points after
touchdowns are credited to the
Jay back.
Turnbull's nearest competitor is Berger, University of
Maryland man, who has garnered 36 points in carrying
over six touchdowns. Next in
order are Kim, of Navy;
Koppe, of Western Maryland;
Doughty, of Western Maryland, all with 30 points; and
Chalmers, of Maryland, with
29 points.
Hudert and Reid, both of
the Jay gridders, are tied with
17 other collegiate scorers for
tenth place on the list. Another Hopkins player, Bauer,
is tied for last place.
Turnbull, who leads the
field, has received considerable
mention from sports writers
in local papers.

S. Jesse Robinson Made Barnstormer Publicity Manager
In order to arouse interest outside of the campus, a very clever
advertising campaign has been
worked out for the Barnstormers'
play. The plays have always been
a social success, but this year it is
hoped to make it even more so.
There will be found next Monday
morning in the postoffice box of
each Hopkins student a small and
attractive oblong sticker advertising
this year's production, "The Black
Flamingo," which is to take place
at the Lyric Theare on December
5th and 6th.
Cooperation Urged

is the wish of the publicity
staff of the Barnstormers that
everyone cooperate with the Club
by displaying these stickers on his
automobile or in ,any other conspicuous place so as to arouse the
interest of the Baltimore public in
the production. The new publicity
staff under the direction of S. Jesse
Robinson feels that with its extensive advertising campaign this year's
undertaking should break a predent by making the show a big
financial success. A high goal is
being set this year so that the Club
might operate on a more pretentious
scale in the future.

KENT TO BEGIN
TALKS NEXT FRIDAY
Frank R. Kent will deliver
the first lecture of his course
in Practical Politics next Friday, November 7. The class,
which is open to all undergraduates, will convene in
Room 101, Remsen Hall.
Mr. Kent, who conducts the
"Great Game of Politics"
column in the Baltimore Sun,
is considered one of the most
prominent commentators on
politics. He is also managing
editor of the Sun, with which
he has been connected since
1898, and editor-owner of
the Maryland Almanac, a
yearly publication. He has
also written four books on
politics, which have had wide
circulation.

JULIAN HUXLEY TO
SPEAK AT HOPKINS
Will Talk on "Travels and
Politics in Africa"
MADE AFRICAN TOUR
To Lecture For Williams Foundation
Julian Huxley, famous English
writer and biologist, will lecture at
Hopkins on Tuesday, November
11, at 5 P. M. in room 120, C. E.
Building, Professor Lancaster,
chairman of the committee on lectures, announced today. Professor
Huxley is the grandson of the faMous Thomas H. Huxley, Victorian
apostle of evolution.
Professor Huxley is professor of
zoology at King's College, London.
He is famous for his research as a
biologist and for his books and
magazine articles. He is co-author
With H. G. Wells of The Science of
Life, which is soon to be published,
and has also written The Individual
in the Animal Kingdom, Essays of
a Biologist, The Stream of Life and
Essays in Popular Science. He has
also been a constant contributor to
well-known English and American
authors.

TURNBULL HEADS
STATE SCORERS
Leading 45 scorers in college football this season, Jack
Turnbull, Hopkins gridiron
star, has, to date chalked up 45
points. Seven touchdowns and
three successful points after
touchdowns are credited to the
Jay back.
Turnbull's nearest competitor is Berger, University of
Maryland man, who has garnered 36 points in carrying
over six touchdowns. Next in
order are Kim, of Navy;
Koppe, of Western Maryland;
Doughty, of Western Maryland, all with 30 points; and
Chalmers, of Maryland, with
29 points.
Hudert and Reid, both of
the Jay gridders, are tied with
17 other collegiate scorers for
tenth place on the list. Another Hopkins player, Bauer,
is tied for last place.
Turnbull, who leads the
field, has received considerable
mention from sports writers
in local papers.

The Optical Society of America,
which is holding its fifteenth annual meeting starting today at the
University of Virginia, has invited
Dr. J. A. Bearden of the Hopkins
faculty to read a paper. Dr. Bearden
will address the assembly on
"Grating Measurements of X-Ray
Lengths and their Significance." On
the same program Prof. A. H.
•Compton of the University of Chicago and Prof. G. Merrit of Cornell. Both of these men will also
discuss different phases of the
X-Ray.

Rifle Club To
Hold Meeting 7oday
There will be an organization
meeting of the Rifle Club today, at
12.30, in the South Loft of Gilman
Hall. Anyone interested in the
Rifle Club, ought to attend this
meeting as matters of importance
to the organization will be discussed.
The Rifle team is selected from
the members of the Rifle Club who
make the best scores.
There are about 35 members
signed up at present and more candidates are urged to come out.

On Monday, November 3, Professor Chinard will speak in French
at the Little Theatre, Howard
street at Franklin, between the acts
of the 8.30 performance of "La
Grande Mate," a French talkingpicture featuring Maurice Chevalier, under the auspices of the Baltimore Group of the Alliance Francaise.
Monsieur Gaston Gille, a distinguished lecturer of the group,
will speak on the topic "La Renaissance de la France Contemporaine" in Civil Engineering Building, Friday, November 21, at 5
P.M. All students are invited to
attend, especially French students.
Prof. Gibert Chinard and Prof.
H. C. Lancaster are members of the
Committee for the Group, here in
Baltimore.
Other lectures by distinguished
Frenchmen are being arranged, as
well as French social and conversational evenings, dramatic and musical events, etc.

S. Jesse Robinson Made Barnstormer Publicity Manager
In order to arouse interest outside of the campus, a very clever
advertising campaign has been
worked out for the Barnstormers'
play. The plays have always been
a social success, but this year it is
hoped to make it even more so.
There will be found next Monday
morning in the postoffice box of
each Hopkins student a small and
attractive oblong sticker advertising
this year's production, "The Black
Flamingo," which is to take place
at the Lyric Theare on December
5th and 6th.
Cooperation Urged

is the wish of the publicity
staff of the Barnstormers that
everyone cooperate with the Club
by displaying these stickers on his
automobile or in ,any other conspicuous place so as to arouse the
interest of the Baltimore public in
the production. The new publicity
staff under the direction of S. Jesse
Robinson feels that with its extensive advertising campaign this year's
undertaking should break a predent by making the show a big
financial success. A high goal is
being set this year so that the Club
might operate on a more pretentious
scale in the future.

KENT TO BEGIN
TALKS NEXT FRIDAY
Frank R. Kent will deliver
the first lecture of his course
in Practical Politics next Friday, November 7. The class,
which is open to all undergraduates, will convene in
Room 101, Remsen Hall.
Mr. Kent, who conducts the
"Great Game of Politics"
column in the Baltimore Sun,
is considered one of the most
prominent commentators on
politics. He is also managing
editor of the Sun, with which
he has been connected since
1898, and editor-owner of
the Maryland Almanac, a
yearly publication. He has
also written four books on
politics, which have had wide
circulation.

Swimming Team
to Organize Next Week

Van Orman Pledges Aid
To Wrestling Association and he set the first practice for
Dr. Ray Van Orman addressed
the organization meeting of the
wrestling team yesterday and
pledged his support to the new
group. The Athletic Association
is unable to finance a wrestling
team; therefore, any coaching that
the team may get must be given
gratis.
Dr. Van Orman promised the
team the use of some wrestling
mats. He also stated that he would
urge all football men to come out
for wrestling, since the sport is
very valuable in building up football men. Jacobson, who precipitated the idea of a wrestling team,
